values:
eh... I can't keep it up anymore.

so that was what writing fan fiction was like...

And now for something different

if I could bring you back to this place, I'm sure you'd like it.
You're synonymous with cold nights, bright lights and the brush of winter air,
I hope that you're not someplace warm, because you hate the heat.
You always said that the best place for you was buck naked in a reseach tent in Antartica
I can see you bare chested and your hair a fluter
You look like a brunnete daisy when your bangs blossom on the ice,
Spread eagled on a fjord, 
you watch the Aura Austrialis dance in the skies of extra long nights.
So if i'd brought you here to this place, whose name escapes me
But provides me with a feeling so forgotten
It'll remind you and I
how this world of fast paces and instant gratification
Makes even the keen eyed blind
to how the frost on the barren branches
makes them glisten like crystals
And the stoplights of green, red and yellow
give each bough the twinkle of Christmas lights
long after the last bit of tinsel is sent to the landfills to die.
In the season where everything sleeps,
this place which I'll take you to if let me
Wakes you up with the rush of surging waves on a New England shore
You'll feel that nordic chill from your ankles to your brow
And I'll embrace you not for the warmth
But because you're super cool.

So in an attempt to write more, I've decided to give this a try: a reborn side story. As Byakuyan's machine gets powered up, the deathperation flames cause it to overload and the machine glows bright red transporting the vongola family somewhere, however as Shoichi points out, it definately isn't choice.

Reborn smirked at the blast from the Vongola guardian's desperation flames shot towards Byakuyan's teleportation device. He nodded with approval at how his young Loser Tsuna had grown over the past few months, defeating Mukuro, the Varia and many of the Millfiore's best agents. Most of all, he was satisfied at the fact that Tsuna had learned to overcome his own shortcomings and rise up to take his destiny. As he saw the number of volts rise, he also appreciated how the whole Vongola family has grown both in terms of mastering their powers and meeting the challenges of this world, overcoming the shocks of the future. This was the first time that they would fight as a complete collective group rather than each one fighting their own individual battle.

Though pleased with the advancements, Reborn's smile turned concerned. His hitman instincts looked up and saw the machine reaching higher levels. The hologram of Byakuyan also grew concerned as the teleportation device started to glow blood red, redder than any storm flame that he's seen. Reborn like the moment where he stood frozen before being transported into the future was unable to move.

"non 7-3?" he thought "no...this is something different."

Shoichi and Spanner also looked up in concern wondering what was wrong with Byakuyan's device. Though great engineers in their own right, they knew of Byakuyan's superior skills at robotics and technology. The transporter continued to glow blood red before launching a large beam at the Vongola family. The Nanimori shrine was enveloped in red glows everyone shielded their eyes and disappeared in a blinding flash of crimson.

Tsuna slowly opened his eyes. He brought himself up to his knees wondering if he and his frieds were dead and if Byakuyan had used the Choice game to destroy the Vongola for good. He rubbed his head as he struggled to stand, he looked around and saw the guardians on the ground.

"Jyuudaime..."

Tsuna looked to find Gokudera seated massaging his neck, while checking all of his boxes on his belt.

"Gokudera-kun!" said Tsuna "are you ok?"

"Yeah..." he said, "But looks like Uri went back to his box. What happened?"
"I don't know, all I remember is speaking to Byakuyan and all of us using our desperation flames. Before I knew it I woke up and found everyone passed out."

One by one the members of the Vongola family rose to their feet. Yamamoto leaned on his sword and smiled at Tsuna, while Ryohei nodded with a shake of his fist. Kyoko, Haru, Bianchi and I-pin dusted off their uniforms while Futa and Basil helped Gianini to his feet. Reborn walked towards Tsuna.

"Ciao-su"
"Reborn, where are we? Is this choice?"
Reborn shook his head and the smile turned into concern.
"I don't think so. We should ask Shoichi and Spanner."

Spanner was seated by a wall sucking on one of his lollipops scratching his head.
Tsuna ran to him.

"Spanner! What is this place? Is this choice?"
Spanner took the lolipop out of his mouth and looked around.
"Vongola...I gotta tell you, don't have a clue. We got transported allright, but I ain't so sure that this is it.
"No..."
They turned and saw Shoichi walking towards them.
"This isn't choice. Look"

The Vongola looked and found themselves on the outskirts of a blown up airfield. In the far distance large flames rose up and from the explosions a large shadow emerged. All that could be seen were thin glowing green eyes. Spanner looked closely and could make the shape of a robot, but this was no Moska. He turned around and he saw the familiar image of Tsuna in deathperation mode, his flames burning brighter than ever but now with his sky lion by his side. But Spanner turned back to the robot, which was twelve time the size of a Moska. Spanner looked at it and thought, "man would I like to get my hands on one of those."

I had forgotten that this corner of the internet exists, the darker, the more somber side of the blog. As I read the previous entries and the anguish that they tried to convey, I had realized the shadow of the events of the past and how saddness and the blackness of being human are...

OH SHUT THE FUCK UP!!!

Basically it's this, this was the freaking emo log! I have to admit I liked the writing style of my darker, somber self, emo-fred so to speak, but I really want to use this as a way to outlet more writing online. It'll give me a way to just write stuff and keep people updated on current writing projects. I realized how removed I've become from writing prose since I focused more on poetry and I want to do this to keep those skills in check. So I had an idea, I'm going to write a fanfic which should be up later after I finish my lesson plans and some reports for work. It might even be up earlier depending on how it goes.

So hopefully you keep reading, it should be an interesting journey, just like how life is.

"If you live the lie long enough it becomes truth. I never thought myself as a great soldier, I never even thought to be a good soldier, but it is what it is Lord General."

DuCouer had a well decorated past. He was awarded the Northern Azurian cross in the Three Year War by leading a small force against a Couchenoir Regiment and sabotaging their artillery peices. The successful raid saved the walls of La Primet from being massacred as they did during the sack of La Primet in what was known as the Seven Years of Tears.

Du Couer was respected and revered by his men, his old unit, the Snow Lions, begged him to stay with them in La Primet. He was neither overly generous nor was he a tyrant, while some men and women ruled their forces, Du Couer led.

"This is why we chose you dear Edguard," said General Roy "as you know L'equipe and I have seen many years of bloodshed and battle. Perhaps it is time for the next generation to take the reigns."

DuCouer nodded quite concerned.

"Does this trouble you?"

DuCouer shook his head and looked up at the old general. The general's face was wrinkled, his beard all snowy white. It was hard to picture that this man was once known as the Mountain Eagle of the Plain, swift and keen eyed. Now his movements were slow and feeble. Only his clever knowledge of tactics and strategy refuse to relinquish their hold.

"No, no sir, not at all," DuCouer smiled "But why not some of the officers that have a bit more experience than I do like Lord Rythan or Lord Excharlis. Surely men of their caliber would be far better at taking control of a regiment as I."

The general sat gingerly down in his chair while the other four members of L'equipe hung down their heads.

"Lord Rythan...Lord Excharlis. Two fine soldiers, two noble lords of Azuria, superb fighters, wouldn't you agree gentlemen."

"Quite so," said General Caral "they stand among the best of Azurian warriors, strong both in sword and firearms. They do as they are told and carry out the battle to countless victories."

"So true," said General Roy "General Caral is not wrong, except for one key fact. Though they may be good soldiers and stewards of the nation. Though they may bring spoil after spoil in every campaign. Their hearts are as black as the rocks of Couchenarria. They do well because our good king pays them well. Azur forbid if our nation were to slip into depression. Where would they be then. Mercenaries they are that lot!"

All was good; the month of July had reached its apex and the sun beamed down on the straw hats of weary farmers. The summer breezes blew softly through the Cardissa Valley in Northern Azuria and flowed over golden fields of wheat and corn and brownish waves of barley and rye.In all of the rural towns and farms, children gathered bales of straw for the annual scarecrow festival. The children spent their afternoons in the shadows of trees, either catching fish or swimming in brooks desperately shutting out the fact that their classes resumed their courses in less than two months. The headmasters and headmistresses however tried their best to be as far away from their classrooms, some even journeyed via carriage to the port cities and boarded ships for destinations unknown.

For Edguard Du Couer, it was nearly eleven years since his last scarecrow festival. He was a young colonel of 26, the youngest colonel in the Northern Azurian Army and only the forth colonel in the entire Azurian Army under the age of 30.  He left the small farming town of Jolie at the age of fifteen to join the Northern Azurian Army. Though injured severely on various occassions, the fates decided to keep Edquard alive. This somewhat supple display of grace bestowed him various career opportunities. His knack for cheating death led to valiant and near romanticized exploits in several small campaigns. Soon Edguard found himself mentioned in various stories over ale and whispers in quiet halls. Due to his favor with the people, the Northern Azurian Army felt that it was time for an adequate promotion.

"It says here," said General Fraidrich Roy "that you've served in the Azurian Army since the prima conscricptum of 985. Quite a young age, don't you think?"

Edguard let off a slight laugh. Seventeen was the minimum age to volunteer during prima conscriptum.

Stuck in a dark void, 
so deployed and feeling irate and annoyed.
Look at the expression,
of all states of the retension of pretension,
making way for the extension of a new dimension.

Wished for the playback
a rewind or reverse to the previous track.
A time when it wasn't all white and black
when we all jammed together front, side to back.

what happened to the mission,
the mission to change one's vision?
We lost the keys to life's ignition,
a sick sad condition of attricion.

All dreams are jaded,
All hopes and memories are blurry and faded,
Ones we once loved or hated
or folks we agreed with or debated

How we pushed them off to the side
and hid behind snide smiles of times we lied.
It didn't matter if we lived or died,
But we'd never reveal the truth inside.

Hypocrisy has becomes synonimous with you and me,
Idiocy and jealousy mixed with vanity, 
make it hard to just be and see.
a hindrance to what it means to be free.

Tears we shed, times we bled,
Times in our lives where we wish we were dead
Alone in cold beds, hard pillows to lay your head.
No one to share thoughts or a loaf of bread.

I thought that having a job would be easy. In all respects, it really is. You follow a certain routine, a rhythm and once you get used to it, it's really easy. When you keep with that rhthm, you keep doing your job, you get paid, you pay your bills and if you're careful, you save a little bit of money to treat yourself once in a while.

The thing that irks me so much isn't the business of the workplace or the hellish one and a half hour commute to work each day. Its everything else. Everything else consists of all sorts of miscellaneous problems that all decide to converge into one inconvenient package. Once you solve one thing or straighten out the wrinkles in one conundrum, you're hit with several puzzles and several issues again.

There are days when everything just drains everything out of you and all that's left is this grouchy old shell.

Bradley Cunningham is an interesting case. He doesn't want to be in this world anymore, he wants to die. Bradley suffers from testicular cancer, the everyday pains, the absolute shortness of breath, the heavy fatigue, the constant operations, the draining of fluid, the constant agony of his everyday. No one visits him except for his granddaughter Lilly, who's only five years old. 

No one went to see him because they all figured that it was his own Goddamned fault. He decided to do all those things, the all out parties, the excessive drinking, divorce after divorce, broken marriages, abandoned sons and daughters. I guess the mere fact that he was still alive was some drastic and killer irony.

The fact of the matter is that Bradley wanted to die, but he didn't want to sign the DNR waver, it was like he wanted God himself to just sweep him away and take him into heaven or cast down to the depths of hell. Either way he didn't care, any exit from this world would have been good.

He thought, "one less bum and good for nothing wouldn't be a loss, hell, It'd be fucking improvement!" He thought about how horrible his life had been, how many people's lives he ruined, how he was a bad father, husband and friend. He remembered all the people he cheated and swindled.

In his prime, he was a criminal mastermind, he had underground connections everywhere, from gun running, to drugs and a whole list of crimes from murder, extortion, kidnapping and theft. But on the outside he seemed extremely legitimate, with so many fronts and covers that money can buy.

He was charged with several counts of murder at one point, it was a huge case, court cameras, CNN coverage, the whole nine yards. Everyone talked about it, from Larry King to Don King, from Letterman all the way to Leno. When all was said and done, Cunningham walked a free man. It was the same process that all previous crimelords followed: pay off the Jury, tamper with the evidence, make witnesses disappear, bribe the judge and the state. The papers described that the allegations against him were preposterous and a hackneyed attempt at trying to extort funds from honest hardworking men. 

It was amazing what money could buy.

However all of that was long ago, now his "fortunes" went to life support- each breath and medication all supported by years and years of ill gotten gains. Drug money went to dextrose, counterfeit dollars to IVs, blood transfusions funded by the assasination contracts fulfilled,

But then he saw Lilly, she had his eyes, and his smile. She was the daughter of his son Bobby from his second marriage. His son refused at first when Lilly insisted that "she wants to go see grampa." She insisted for weeks on end.

Eventually Bobby gave in and said "ok sweetheart, go ahead." He drove her to the hospital and went as far as Brian's room. He had all kinds of tubes sticking out of him, he was so pale, so ghastly, far from the Kingpin he once was.

Lilly walked up to him

"Hi grampa Brian. I'm Lilly"

Brian could only listen, he couldn't speak due to all the drugs he was on. He looked at her and tried to smile. All he could do was pat her softly on the head.

"I heard you can't talk too good, but that's ok. At school today, they had a bunny rabbit from the zoo. I got to pet it, it was really soft"

Brian felt a warmth inside him. He couldn't really make out what else she was saying but it made him happy. That soft aura of innocence that surrounded his granddaughter was a comfort to him. He took solace in the fact that there was hope in her future, a future which would never lead to the same fate as his. He wanted her to keep talking for hours and about anything.

"That's...wonderful...Lilly..."

He saw her light up and smile.

"Hee hee, looks like you can speak after all grampa!"

He made another valiant effort, every muscle in his body, his lungs and his throat, made even uttering the slightest of sounds painful. 

"Are...you...being good?"

"Of course grampa, I am."

"Beautiful..."

"How about you grampa? Have you been good?"

It was a sharp question, it hit his soul like a knife, but she never knew the truth, she never read the stories. For Bradley, it was time to be honest, just this once.

"No sweetie...grampa's been real bad...real bad."

She looked at him.

"No, you look good to me."

The old gangster had never cried in his life, not at his daughter's wedding, not at his mother's funeral, not when his brother was shot. He didn't shed a tear when his cousin was sent to the electric chair for a crime that Bradley was responsible for, nor did he give a moment's thought to giving the order to have his eldest son eliminated.

That one moment, those six simple words from the most innocent of minds, the most honest of hearts and perhaps the truest judges of character, made the old man swell with emotion.

from the mouth of babes...

Willy Armstrong walked through the crowded streets of Manhattan and breathed deep. He sucked in the raw aroma of the New York Metro area. It was like a sick, twisted and rather pleasant aroma of warm baked bread, taxi exhaust, fresh bagels, hot cheap coffee for 99 cents. It smelled full of commerce, e-trading, trends, pop-culture and modernity. It gave a scent of hard working middle class America, nine to fivers, slaves to white collars, subway taking, rise up early, live in Connecticutt or Westchester, commuting folk. 

Willy was one of those guys. He was lucky enough to get a degree in Finace and land himself a job for Chase Manhattan. He was a Loan Consultant, he could tell you tales for hours about Escrow, Re-Financing, Consolidation, Intrest rates, Mortgages, Car Loans, just about anything to do with the "You need money, we have money, just pay it back or else" business.

Willy really liked his job. He liked helping people. In grammar school, when they took those tests which told you what job you'd have, he was told that he would be in some sort of humanitarian relief, like Unicef or the Peace Corp.

He was also a pretty nice guy. All the guys at work really liked him always asking him to go bowling and to join their poker games on weekends. He liked the Yankees, like everybody at work, and the Jets which everyone at work liked too. He was also dashing, charming and sweet. He worked out everyday after work resulting in a share of the smiles and winks from the single ladies. In the bathroom, the ladies would always talk about him.

"Oh, did you see him today, he was wearing some CK shirts"
"Oh yeah, he smelled so good, he had cologne on: Ralph Lauren I think"
"Its a shame..."
"That he's married"
"Lucky cooze"
"Yeah, lucky ass cooze."

Jenna Armstrong however was no cooze. She was a headstrong, independent woman who spoke her mind whenever she felt like it. What made her special was that she knew the appropriate times to do so. She never nagged her husband on the menial issues, but would be ready to light a fire under his butt with something serious. She was never cold and knew when to comfort her husband and when to leave him alone.

Like her husband, she also worked in the Loan Industry, she was a Loan Consultant for Citibank. At night, Willy and she had conversations of who had the better rates, service and options. But at the time, Jenna would always win. At work she was like her husband, nice, courteous, helpful and efficient. 

Home for the Armstrongs was Irvington, NY, just off the Tappan Zee Bridge in Westchester County. They had a two-bedroom appartment overlooking the Hudson, at a manageable 1000 per month. With their salaries they could easily afford the rent, and save up enough to go to Greece for a week last year.

Travis Tsing woke up from a three day hangover. His jaw all skewed, his mind warped and his memory swiss cheesed by a bar he forgot the name of. His butt and back hurt from when he fell flat on the floor of a Rockland Dinner, which he went to as a kid, but couldn't bring himself to remember the name. He was nauseous with dysentary with a slight case of indigestion. 

He decided to call in at work.

When he returned to his job, the next day, he told his co-workers and his supervisors about how he acquired the three day hangover. At first the office got a pretty good laugh out of it, but later on in the week he was made aware of how calling in due to a three day hangover was a really bad idea. 

He had thought that they viewed him as somewhat of a shut in, who would never have experiences involving three day hangovers. He never displayed it. As a kid, he was a good boy, he shared his toys, he always said his please's and thank you's, he did just as he was told. The thing that was a pain to him was that he always remained the same way. No matter how tough he tried to be, or how much time he put in the gym, or nights that he drank himself to a stuppor he was always that kind little boy trying to make it in a big man's world. 

Perhaps those during those days and nights he tried to dispell the image of being such a prude. The real truth of the matter was that he really was a prude, like a pup in a kennel of hounds.

He was also young. Like all youths, he had that drive in him that wanted to impress and be the best, he always wanted to go the extra mile. But like most youths, he didn't want to make the sacrifice or suffer to attain his goals. He blamed society for making him subconciously want the easy way out of life. As a boy growing up in Pyongyang, life was never easy, his father desperately tried to leave the corrupt military, while his mother worked at a local clinic. 

Something in him remembered the struggles he and his family faced. It was time to rekindle the fires in him again.

Audrey du Couer is a pretty girl, she has nice brown eyes and long hair. She is an editor for a local magazine, she had aspirations of being an editor for a big time sports magazine, but she was quickly turned down for a girl the company found more "suitable" for the company's needs. She never considered herself beautiful, attractive, sexy or even cute. She always looked down on her slender body and how it never fit society's standards for beauty, attractiveness, sex appeal or even cuteness. She hated herself. But she wasn't a cutter, nor was she a drunk, nor a drug addict. It was one of the worse kinds: the internalizer. 

She would shrug it off and let all the emotion just swell in her. After she was denied the job, she was very upset. At the moment she was ready to burst out crying she perked herself up, fixed her suit, packed her things and walked out the door with all the confidence of a modern woman. 

But it was all fake. Inside, her self confidence was shot. All of the catcalls from kindergarten, grammar school, high school and college came swimming back to her, like a bloodied pool of frenzied sharks. And there she was in the middle, slowly bleeding, with each shark coming in for a swift bite.

On the outside, she smiled, walking the streets without a care in the world. The streets welcomed her with open arms, smiling at any strangers whose eyes met hers. She went to a coffee shop that nobody knew and there she sipped on a double chocolate mocha. She looked like a girl who had just been kissed for the very first time, and there she was in a nice little corner of a mom and pop coffee house, staring at the passer-bys outside, contemplating and dreaming of her new romance.

When she was home, she would still be fine. She would go to the kitchen, fix herself a very simple dinner, watch some TV, maybe call her dad and then get ready for bed.

Once she hit the pillow, the sobs would start. The sorrow, the grief and the feelings of sheer inadequacy, forced her to burry herself in the folds of her blankets.

As the sun rose, she would be refreshed. She take a warm shower while singing showtunes from Carousel. She'd make a small breakfast consisting of Portuguese Rolls and some coffee. She'd put on a new suit and go to another interview.

Her mornings went on like this for a few days until she finally landed the editor position for a state funded guidance couselor magazine/newsletter. The pay was lousy, but was enough to pay the bills, buy food and set a little bit aside.

As time passed, Audrey was able to even lie to herself and really suppress all of that negativity deep down. She pushed it into the far back end of her sub-conciousness and hoped that such feelings never resurfaced.

Though she did feel better about herself and life, her feelings of inadequacy were still there. It was only a question of when would they surface again.

Betty Seawach is a happy grandmother of 17. She lives in Elmsford, up the street from the movie theater and the Sam's Club. She bakes for her grandkids all the time and teaches the eldest grandaughter Sara how to cook. 

She lost her husband Harry in 1963 to meningitis. The two met in London on January 4th 1941. The United States Army Band was in town, Harry was the first chair trumpeter. The group performed In The Mood, Harry had the trumpet solo. 

Later that night, he had Betty's heart as well. She was all of 17, he was 23. She lived in London, he lived in Elmsford. They wrote each other letters, but since Harry travelled around a lot, they seldom saw each other.

One day the letters stopped coming. Betty was worried. Her mother told her that the chances of a trumpeter seeing any combat were slim.

"I would guess my dear," she said "that if we would all put down our bloody guns and played music instead, we wouldn't have as many problems as we do today."

She took solace in the fact that he was more of a performer than a soldier. She would laugh at the thought of him charging up a trench playing Louis Armstrong with a company of soldier's following his lead.

The postman came the next day with a letter. It was from Harry, he was placed on active duty and would be shipping out for Portsmouth.

Luckily he surived the war and took her to America.

Harry and Betty had five children, Harry Jr., Elizabeth, Tommy, Brandon and Linda. 

She misses him alot.

Langston Avery was sick of his job. He wanted to wake up the next morning and find the world in dessolation: no world, no work, no responsibilities. He wanted more than anything to be the last remaining person on earth, wandering far and wide, scrounging the ruins of cities, enjoying all the comforts and joys that he was denied all this time. 

Langston pictured Midtown Manhattan, all of the fine suits that he could never afford, every pair of Bostonians that he could never wear, all the CK ties that would never don his bargain bin blue collared shirt, all of these articles of clothing, lined up from one end of 42nd street to to the other end and he strutting down in the Saturday Night Fever style.

He'd go into McDonalds and eat 40 chicken nuggets and fill up a large drink cup with soft serve and when he felt nauseous, he'd go to one of the deep fryers and vomit.
